When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from the one in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor compared to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all, they still need the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself goes beyond cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies that are intrinsically conditioned rather than socially conditioned.
For example, we could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
Massive car ownership also leads to a higher incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the resulting injuries.

The use of ships to transport goods is by far the most efficient way to move large numbers of people and goods across the oceans.

The work of the navy has traditionally been to ensure that your country maintains the capacity to move your people and your goods, while interfering with your enemy's capacity to move his people and his goods.

One of the most remarkable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic Campaign during World War II. The Americans were trying to cross the Atlantic Ocean to send soldiers and equipment to help Britain.
At the same time, the German navy, using mainly submarines, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have conquered Great Britain as it did the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time about 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains of Iran.
Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them close by for easy access to milk, hair, meat, and hides.

Domesticated goats were usually kept in herds that roamed the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more common term of shepherds. These pastoral methods are still in use today.
Wagonways were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the tracks for wagons were simply made of parallel wooden planks, they allowed the horses that pulled them to reach greater speeds and pull heavier loads than on the slightly more accident-prone roads of the day.
Croissants were introduced early on to keep the tracks in place. However, it was soon realized that the tracks would be more effective if they were equipped with a metal strip on top.
It has become a common practice, but the iron has caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.

Their predecessors, the australopiths, did not walk upright as usual.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a handwritten manuscript signed by Congress President John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few blocks away, to the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as the "Dunlap Broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy arrived in London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that are known to exist, they are the oldest copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because the behaviour of drivers cannot be predicted with 100% certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonable range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be mathematically approximated.
In order to better represent traffic flow, relationships were established between the three main characteristics: (1) throughput, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relations help with planning, design, and operation of road facilities.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC, and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans and the Merinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who after having destroyed it, rebuilt it and named it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all of Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, you can easily find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tagines, pottery, leather goods, hookahs and all sorts of souvenirs, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town located at the extreme east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava from the volcano Nyiragongo, which buried most of the city's streets, particularly the downtown area.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside Goma should be subject to research to understand the state of the fighting that continues in the province of North Kivu.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the volcano Nyiragongo as well as for treks of gorilla tracking among the least expensive in Africa.

Combined with its relative inaccessibility, "Timbuktu" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa and borders the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River forms the southern border.
The total area of the park is 19,500 km2, which is divided into 14 ecozones, each with its own unique fauna.
It is one of the best-known amusement parks in South Africa and is considered the jewel in the crown of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entrance and conservation fees for the park.
It may be advantageous to obtain a Wild Card that gives access to some parks in South Africa, as well as to all the national parks in South Africa.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove forest in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the hinterland of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The Indian part of the forest is called the Sundarbans National Park.
Forests, however, are not composed solely of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which about a third is covered with swampy areas.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer there.

The Oyapock Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the towns of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers rise to a height of 83 meters; it is 378 meters long and has two lanes 3.50 meters wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it wasn't opened to traffic until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational by September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guaraní were the largest indigenous group living in what is now eastern Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence farming.
Other indigenous tribes that populated the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived primarily through fishing, hunting, or gathering.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP) whose value is equivalent to one British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the islands located in Stanley, across from the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a commonly accepted currency in the islands, while at Stanley, credit cards and US dollars are also often accepted.
On nearby islands, credit cards are unlikely to be accepted, even if it is possible that British and American currencies will be. Speak to the owners in advance to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falklands outside the islands, so change it before you leave the islands.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang on either side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
Firstly, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth and narrow sole.
